facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 156 of 1965 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 12, 1963 of the Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Application No. 315 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 156 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 12, 1963 of the Bombay High Court  Nagpur Benc

facts.text: Model Mills Nagpur is a public limited company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Model Mills, Nagpur  hereinafter referred to as the Mills  is a public limited companypany incorporated under the Indian Companies Act.

facts.text: On July 18, 1959, Central Government took over management of Model Mills under s.18A of Industries Development and Regulation Act 1951 and appointed 3rd respondent as authorised Controller.

anchor.surface_text: On July 18, 1959, in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 18-A of the Industries  Development and Regulation  Act, 1951, the Central Government took over the management of the Mills and appointed the 3rd respondent as the authorised Controller of the Mills.

facts.text: On March 25, 1960, State of Bombay notified Model Mills as relief undertaking under ss.3 and 4 of Bombay Relief Undertakings Special Provisions Act 1958 for one year from March 26, 1960 to March 25, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On March 25, 1960 the State of Bombay  number the State of Maharashtra , in exercise of the powers companyferred by ss. 3 and 4 of the Bombay Relief Undertakings  Special Provisions  Act, 1958  hereinafter referred to as the Bombay Act  made a numberification declaring the Mills to be a relief undertaking for a period of one year companymencing from March 26, 1960 and ending with March 25, 1961.

facts.text: Appellants are eight permanent employees of Model Mills at the relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, eight in number, were, at the relevant time, the permanent employees of the Mills.

facts.text: On December 15, 1960, employees abstained from work while Bombay Act notification was in force.

anchor.surface_text: On December 15, 1960, when the numberification made by the State Government under the Bombay Act was in force, the employees abstained from work.

facts.text: 1st respondent, Factory Manager of Model Mills, issued show cause notices to employees for joining illegal strike.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the 1st respondent who is the Factory Manager of the Mills issued numberices to the employees to show cause why they should number be dismissed from service for joining an illegal strike.

facts.text: On January 6, 1961, Factory Manager dismissed the employees from service.

anchor.surface_text: On January 6, 1961 the Factory Manager passed orders dismissing the employees from service.

facts.text: On January 12, 1961, employees filed application in Bombay High Court for writ of mandamus directing reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: On January 12, 1961 the employees filed an application in the High Court of Bombay for the issue of a writ of mandamus directing the employees to be reinstated in service.

facts.text: On April 4, 1961, exemption of Model Mills from s.16 of State Act was withdrawn.

anchor.surface_text: On April 4, 1961, the exemption of the Mills from the application of s. 16 of the Central Provinces and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act  XXIII of 1947   herein- after called the State Act  was made.

facts.text: On April 25, 1961, employees filed applications before Assistant Commissioner of Labour for reinstatement with back wages.

anchor.surface_text: On April 25, 1961 the employees filed applications before the Assistant Commissioner Sup.CI./76-12 of Labour claiming reinstatement with back wages.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed writ petition filed by employees with liberty to file fresh if necessary, as prosecuting before Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the Writ Petition filed by the employees with liberty to file a fresh petition, if necessary, since they were prosecuting their applications for relief of reinstatement before the Assistant Commissioner of Labour.

facts.text: On September 29, 1961, Assistant Commissioner allowed employees' applications, held no illegal strike, set aside dismissal, directed reinstatement with back wages.

anchor.surface_text: In and by his order dated September 29, 1961, the Assistant Commissioner allowed the applications filed by the employees. He held that as there was numberillegal strike the orders of dismissal were unsustainable and should be set aside. He directed that the employees should be reinstated with back wages.

facts.text: Mills filed revision applications against Assistant Commissioner's orders to State Industrial Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the orders passed by the Assistant Commissioner, the Mills preferred applications in revision to the State Industrial Court.

facts.text: On February 16, 1962, State Industrial Court allowed Mills' revision, held applications before Assistant Commissioner not maintainable, but agreed no illegal strike.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated February 16, 1962, the Industrial Court allowed the revision applications filed by the Mills on the ground that the applications before the Assistant Commissioner were number maintainable. On the merits, the Industrial Court agreed with the Assistant Commissioner that there was numberillegal strike.

facts.text: Employees filed application under Arts. 226 and 227 in Bombay High Court for certiorari to quash dismissal orders and direct reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the orders of the Industrial Court, the employees filed an applicaton under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ of certiorari to quash the orders of dismissal passed by the Factory Manager and to direct their reinstatement with back wages.

facts.text: On August 12, 1963, Bombay High Court dismissed the writ petition, held no right to reinstatement under common law or s.16 due to exemption.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated August 12, 1963 the High Court dismissed the Writ Petition filed by the employees. The High Court has held that the right to claim reinstatement is number a right which is available to an employee under the Common Law and that the relief of reinstatement is a special right which has been companyferred on an employee under S. 16 of the State Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court and Industrial Court orders, restored Assistant Commissioner's award.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the judgment of the High Court and the order of the Industrial Court are set aside and the award made by the Assistant Commissioner of Labour is restored. The appeal is allowed and the appellants will have their companyts in this Court paid by respondent No.

facts.text: State Industrial Court found there was no illegal strike.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated February 16, 1962, the Industrial Court allowed the revision applications filed by the Mills on the ground that the applications before the Assistant Commissioner were number maintainable. On the merits, the Industrial Court agreed with the Assistant Commissioner that there was numberillegal strike.

facts.text: Assistant Commissioner of Labour found there was no illegal strike.

anchor.surface_text: In and by his order dated September 29, 1961, the Assistant Commissioner allowed the applications filed by the employees. He held that as there was numberillegal strike the orders of dismissal were unsustainable and should be set aside.

facts.text: Notification under Bombay Act extended on March 8, 1961 for further one year.

anchor.surface_text: This numberification was extended by the State Government on March 8, 1961 for a further period of one year.

facts.text: Employees' applications to Assistant Commissioner filed within six months of dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed their applications within the period specified in S. 16 of the State Act.

facts.text: s.16 of State Act made applicable to textile industry from March 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that s. 16 is made applicable to the textile industry with effect from. March 1, 1951 by a numberification dated February 22, 1951.

facts.text: Supreme Court held dismissal was wrongful.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the dismissal was therefore finally companycluded in favour of the employees.

holdings.text: S. 16 only recognises the right of a dismissed employee, in appropriate cases, to claim reinstatement but does not confer the right. The section provides the procedure for enforcing the right.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already stated, S. 16 only recognises the right of a dismissed employee, in appropriate cases, to claim reinstatement but does not confer the right. The section provides the procedure for enforcing the right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents such as Western India Automobile recognize jurisdiction to order reinstatement post-1947 ID Act; s.16 is machinery/procedural provision, not source of right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bombay Act exemption targets statutory provisions/remedies; underlying right survives as it pre-exists statute; withdrawal revives remedy without abrogating rights.

holdings.text: The right can be enforced by a dismissed employee by resorting to the provisions of s. 16 of the Act provided he makes the application within six months from the date of his dismissal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Withdrawal merely ends suspension, restores pre-exemption status quo; no retrospectivity as dispute continuing per Birla Brothers principle.

holdings.text: The validity of the dismissal was therefore finally concluded in favour of the employees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Timely filing post-withdrawal; right and remedy available without retrospectivity.

precedents.citation: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal, Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal, Bombay 1 . In that case, the Federal Court companysidered the larger question about the powers of industrial tribunals in all its aspects and rejected the argument of the employer that to invest the tribunal with jurisdiction to order reinstatement amounts to giving it authority to make a companytract between two persons when one of them is unwilling to enter into a companytract of employment at all. This argument, it was observed, overlooks the fact that when a dispute arises about the employment of a person at the instance of a trade union or a trade union objects to the employment of a certain person, the definition of industrial dispute would companyer both those cases.

precedents.case_name: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: jurisdiction of Industrial Tribunal to direct reinstatement of dismissed employee as industrial dispute
precedents.cited_holding: there appears no logical ground to exclude an award of reinstatement from the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: Birla Brothers, Ltd. v. Modak 1  has firmly established the principle that for a dispute which originated before the Industrial Disputes Act came into force but was in existence on the date when that Act became law, the Act applied to the dispute since it was in existence and companytinuing on that date and numberquestion of giving retrospective effect to the Act arose. At p. 22 1, the learned Chief Justice, Harries, who spoke for the Court stated thus In my judgment, the Act of 1947 clearly applies to the present dispute without any question arising of giving the Act any retrospective effect. It is true the dispute arose before the Act was passed, but on April 1, 1947, when the Act came into force, the dispute was in existence and companytinuing.

precedents.cited_proposition: Act applies to dispute existing and continuing when Act comes into force even if originated earlier without retrospective effect
precedents.cited_holding: the Act must apply to any dispute existing after it came into force, numbermatter when that dispute companymenced

anchor.surface_text: As we have already stated, S. 16 only recognises the right of a dismissed employee, in appropriate cases, to claim reinstatement but does not confer the right. The section provides the procedure for enforcing the right.

edges.explanation: h3 holds right enforceable under s.16 within six months from dismissal, addressing i2 on application right post-exemption

anchor.surface_text: The right can be enforced by a dismissed employee by resorting to the provisions of s. 16 of the Act provided he makes the application within six months from the date of his dismissal.

In the result the judgment of the High Court and the order of the Industrial Court are set aside and the award made by the Assistant Commissioner of Labour is restored. The appeal is allowed and the appellants will have their costs in this Court paid by respondent No.

anchor.surface_text: This argument proceeds on a fallacy. There is no question of the notification withdrawing an exemption being prospective or retrospective.

In the result the judgment of the High Court and the order of the Industrial Court are set aside and the award made by the Assistant Commissioner of Labour is restored. The appeal is allowed and the appellants will have their costs in this Court paid by respondent No.

edges.explanation: h6 holds applications maintainable as filed within s.16 period, addressing i2 on right to apply

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed their applications within the period specified in S. 16 of the State Act. The High Court was in error in holding that the applications were not maintainable.

In the result the judgment of the High Court and the order of the Industrial Court are set aside and the award made by the Assistant Commissioner of Labour is restored. The appeal is allowed and the appellants will have their costs in this Court paid by respondent No.
